Your company wants to privatize water and charge people for it. The other stuff sounds wonderful, but I am not distracted.

In my time leading Public Affairs and Communications for the Coca-Cola Company we initiated a number of sustainability and economic empowerment projects. I was consistently impressed by the number of women who took advantage of those programs.

A fresh water well drilled in a sub-Saharan Africa village reduced the incidence of disease, but also eliminated the great amount of time women (and it was always women and girls) were required to spend transporting water from the local river. The women invested the extra time and clean water into expanding their vegetable farming, leading to more and better crops to sell at the local market and higher cash income for their families. Their daughters had time for school. The extra money might have purchased a few more Cokes, but it also provide the financing for the children's education.

Similarly our MDCs - where we set up entrepreneurs in small distribution centers - attracted many women looking for a business start. Also, as I remember, nearly 50% of those centers begun by men had women running the finances. These centers have created a network of female business leaders across Africa who now demand and receive the respect of the societies in which they live.

Once individuals are empowered, it becomes much more difficult to subjugate them socially, politically or religiously.

Now, this article is very compelling. Adderall is very abused, and even more so, overly prescribed. However, saying it should be banned is a bit extreme. It's not just prescribed to people with ADHD, it's also prescribed for narcolepsy because the only way to help a narcoleptic is to treat the symptoms with medication and therapy.

Also, people who *truly* have ADHD benefit tremendously from Adderall. After all, I do. I spent the first 20 years of my life struggling with the simplest tasks. I couldn't make important phone calls because I couldn't even finish a sentence without losing my focus and trailing off. Sometimes I wouldn't even remember I was talking to someone because something took my attention. Class was a nightmare. I never heard a word of a lecture. I couldn't even keep my attention for a short movie, or an adult television show. I was a complete scattered wreck. And, well, I still am. Technically. Because I can't do anything about it, except what I am doing: medication and therapy.

Adderall, when prescribed to someone who really have problems, and who do not abuse them, is a wonderful thing. I have always been a hermit because I can't stay focused on anything people are saying to me. After a few words I'm just gone. Adderall keeps my focus, lets me communicate, watch movies, pay attention to (and even enjoy!) class lectures. ADHD also tends to come with anxiety disorders, so, in me personally, Adderall helps with anxiety.

Preventive medical care can increase health care cost.  It's no more complicated than a scenario in which the malady prevented costs less than the preventive activity.  In the 70's, podiatrists made a windfall by essentially trimming toenails in order to prevent hangnails.  If, for the sake of argument, the rate of hangnails/infection and the cost to treat are low enough (think a prevalence of 1 in 10 becoming infected absent this treatment, a cost to treat the afflicted of $200, and a $25 "preventive" trimming), you've spent $250 to avoid a cost of $200.  I do believe there are many many preventive services that are good investments, but it's not a hard-and-fast rule.  It sure does help sell comprehensive health insurance for all though.

Mr. Bartlett observes that health coverage includes "routine maintenance" (periodic doctor visits and such). True enough, but he then makes the leap to suggest that this coverage increases the cost of health care. Here he is mistaken.

Some coverage, such as for routine eye exams, amounts to little more than prepaid expenses (not insurance for unforeseen events). It is possible that such coverage does increase the overall cost of health care by insulating beneficiaries from the true costs. But preventive medical care does not increase health care costs.

Ensuring that people receive early diagnosis and care reduces the likelihood and cost of treatment down the road. It also reduces spread of diseases, again lowering overall health care costs to the nation as a whole.

This is why preventive care coverage is required by the Affordable Care Act. Eliminating this coverage would be a model example of being "penny wise, pound foolish."

At least some of the laws of science - conservation of energy, laws of motion and gravity, nuclear reactions, atomic properties (and therefore chemistry), electrodynamics - can be observed to work over distances of billions of light-years, and therefore billions of years into the past. We can reasonably conclude through observation that the laws we observe now were the same laws that applied to ancient Greeks, a mere two or three millenia ago. So as far as the physical world is concerned, the Greeks lived in essentially the same world we do.

The concept that Greeks could have lived in a different world, in which someone like Zeus could exist as a daily reality fails in the face of our scientific knowledge. Of course, Gutting could claim that our science is simply wrong, or a cultural construct - I find it hard to swallow that, for example, Special Relativity works only because we believe in it. I even find it hard to swallow that Gutting really thinks this - perhaps he has just not examined all the implications of his speculation?
